record.title: Michael Ryan interviewed by Devin Becker
record.transcript:
[00:00:00] PART 1
DB: Here we are. Hey, it's March 18th and this is an interview with Michael Ryan. Okay, the interview kind of has two parts. The first part I just sort of ask about your current practice is. It's based on the survey Collier and I did for an article about two years ago of like younger poets and how they work with digital media. Those are meant to be sort of short answer, just about how you save, how you type and stuffs like that. Then, we'll kind of talk more about the arch of your career and different ways your process has changed or not changed in accordance with history, technology, culture. So if you don't mind, please state your name, date of birth, and where we are.
MR: Michael, Ryan, 24th of February 1946, and I believe were in Irvine, California.
DB: Okay. This is kind of how you work currently. What genres do you work in as a writer?
MR: I write prose and poetry, essays, nonfiction, and mostly poems.
DB: You're primary genre is poetry then?
MR: Yeah.
DB: I know these answers. Some of these will be repetitive and if it's like, you're like, "Okay, I answered that," just tell me.
MR: That's fine.
DB: Okay. What kinds of devices do you own or have access to for your writing, in terms of computer devices?
MR: I have a desktop computer and an iPad. I don't use the iPad much but sometimes for internet stuff.
DB: Do you have a desktop computer here? Do you have one also at your office that you work on?
MR: I don't use it.
DB: You don't use it?
MR: Yeah.
DB: Okay. So, that's your main computer for composing?
MR: That's it.
DB: That's it?
MR: Pretty much, yeah.
DB: What operating system are you using?
MR: Microsoft word.
DB: Is it a PC or a MAC?
MR: It's a PC.
DB: It's a PC, okay. Do you use computers exclusively for your work or do you use both physical and visual environments?
MR: What does that mean?
DB: I mean, do you work on paper and digitally? Do you go back and forth or are you at the point where you work primarily on the computer?
MR: I draft poems by hand and then I'll go back to the computer and go sometimes back and forth. Prose, I write on the computer.
DB: Okay. Is there a point during, well, we'll talk about this later. At which point do you kind of like, if you're writing by hand, like when do you move to the computer?
MR: Yeah, it depends. Just it seems to be finished enough to make a tart copy.
DB: Okay. Do you have any prewriting or notes to these things or are they usually...?
MR: Yeah, again, it depends on the piece. They're all very different but sometimes there are a lot of notes, sometimes there's not much. I don't usually take notes on the computer. I usually will do that by hand.
DB: Do you save those prewriting notes, the physical copies? Do you keep them somewhere or...?
MR: I keep everything, yeah. My papers are at the University of Virginia. Theoretically, someday I should be sending what's accumulated to them.
DB: How do you save your digital files, like your poem files, etc?
MR: I try to do them in terms of the draft numbers, like I will save the title. Sometimes, I'll put the date if it seems germane but I will put numbers so that the first draft that goes on the computer is one, and so forth.
DB: Do you save them all in one folder? What's the folder system? Are you saving them just like poetry folder?
MR: Yeah, no, just one. Currently, it's Poems 2012 – because that was when I finished my last book of poems.
[00:05:00]
MR: They're kind of arranged by book.
DB: Okay. Once you have the poem on a computer, do you have it printed out to revise it that way?
MR: Yes.
DB: Do you save paper copies of those drafts?
MR: Yeah. Well, usually. I can get sloppy about it but I try to save most.
DB: How do you do that? Do you put them in files? Do you put them in boxes?
MR: For years, my office is filled with stacks of brown boxes as you might remember. It's all a big mess and a big pile.
DB: Some lucky art someday will have it, like, it's several months of work.
MR: Yeah, a month a year, or perhaps not so lucky.
DB: Were there also like brown bags too, or was it just boxes? I feel like I remember paper bags at the...?
MR: No, there were not brown bags.
DB: They were boxes. My memory...
MR: That's a screened memory, Devin. Do you think I'm sloppier that I already am?
DB: No, I picture you like with grisly bags full of your walking bag.
MR: It's pathetic but not quite pathetic.
DB: I know. Do you back up your digital copies? Do you have some sort of like, do you put them on a hard drive somewhere else or any of that?
MR: No, I hope it has a back up. There's a system on it. I think it does. I think it backs it up automatically.
DB: Okay. Are you using something like Dropbox or any of those kind of cloud things?
MR: No, I'm not.
DB: Okay. Once you're finished with the poem, how do you save that sort of finished piece? Does that go into a manuscript file? What happens once you feel like the poem is done?
MR: Well again, when it's done, it's just number whatever, 15 of that particular poem and it just stays in that folder until it's time for a book. And then, I will transfer the latest, the final draft of everything into some other place so that it's just the final drafts. Then, there's always galleys and proofread stuff and so that becomes a separate folder.
DB: Okay. That's the quick digital beginning part of it. Now, we'll kind of talk more dramatically, with larger scope. How long have you been writing professionally, is the first question? By professionally, I mean in a way that you are sort of supporting yourself or that it has led to jobs or something like that.
MR: The first poem I published was in 1970. So, 44 years.
DB: What was your first poem?
MR: Actually, the first published poem, it was in my first book. It was 1970. Before that, there were a couple but the first one and the oldest poem in my New and Selected is a poem called Hitting Fungoes.
DB: Yeah, I like that one. Please describe kind of the arc of your career, like kind of education all the way through what your current kind of position?
MR: I've been teaching all of that time.
DB: I mean, even before that, like your kind of education leading up to that too.
MR: When I went to Notre Dame, there weren't any writing workshops. I was an English major and I was interested in being, I was the editor of the literary magazine at Notre Dame when I was a senior there and I wrote extremely bad undergraduate poems. I then went to Claremont graduate school and Claremont here, and was going to get a PhD in English and was writing poems all of that time and decided to leave after three semesters, and dropped out, went to Cambridge, lived with some friends and I worked in a bookstore in Harvard Square.
There's a funny story about after I quit at Claremont. I was sort of a lame duck there. It was during the time of the Cambodia invasion...
[00:10:00]
MR: ...and it was a very charged political time. I had gone through Iowa City and expected that since I was a poet, all the faculty on the workshop would want to read my poems. Kindly, George Starbuck met with me and I handed him a manuscript of poems and he put it in his desk drawer. We just talked for a few minutes. That was it and I left. After I quit the PhD program at Claremont, I got a letter from George Starbuck saying "You're accepted to the workshop. Why don't you apply?"
DB: That's nice.
MR: Wasn't it?
DB: Yeah.
MR: A miracle never could happen now or come close to such a thing, but anyways he was a sweet man and apparently saw something in my poems and so then I went to Iowa from 19970–1974. I got MFA there. I couldn't get a job after getting an MFA so they kindly offered to put me up for another year. I worked in the Iowa Review as a poetry editor. They said, "If you're going to stay, you have to go back in the PhD program because we have to have a way to get for you to graduate."
So, I did that. I worked on the Iowa Review, still couldn't get a job after the next year and the fourth year between the summer. After my third year, I got a call from the Yale University Press saying I won the Yale Series of Younger Poets and so I went back to Iowa for a fourth year finish. Up my PhD, they put me on the faculty for my last semester there. When I went to Southern Methodist University from there for four years, I then directed the MFA program, which is now at Warren Wilson. While it was at Goddard, while the director Ellen Voigt had her Guggenheim year. From there, I was there two years, I guess. No, one year and then I went to Princeton for two years and to Charlottesville, Virginia at the University of Virginia as a visitor and also mostly at Warren Wilson for those all those years and then came here. I've been here since 1991. It was at California-Irvine.
DB: All right.
MR: Was that too long?
DB: No, that's exactly what I'm looking for. I mean, just sort of start, this is what happened, you know. Now, I'm going to kind of ask you more specifically about your writing practice. I kind of delineated it into like three stages, the first being kind of like compositional prewriting generative stage. The second being the kind of revision stage and then the third being the kind of organizational archival stage by which I mean, like when things are starting to be finished and putting into books and then what you do with those publications and how you kind of work with that archival stuff. Does that make sense if that matches up with your writing process enough to talk then...?
MR: Sort of.
DB: Usually, it will just kind of go and you'll probably answer questions that I have later and we'll just going to go forward. So what I like to talk about is kind of like how you are writing initially in the beginning parts of your career and then kind of to think about how that changed. If there were sort of significant changes, what those were and stuff like that. Would you please describe kind of your typical compositional practices when you first started writing professionally like at Iowa and maybe a little past that area? How were you writing? Were you using handwriting? Were you using a typewriter? Did you keep a notebook, things like that?
[00:15:00]
MR: I don't think I kept a notebook in those days. When I went to Iowa, I was writing five poems a week. It was fun and easy. Hey, this is easy and occasionally changing a word or two, and all by hand. I mean I would have to type it up at some point and I've got a typewriter in those days, a manual typewriter, I think. That changed in my second year there. I guess I just hit a wall and saw that I could not write the poem that I wanted, hoped to write in one draft and multiple drafting much more frequently, almost always. Most of the poems in my first book were written that way, and not the old way.
DB: How did that work, like just nitty gritty wise?
MR: Well, again, it's always been going back in. I mean, it's mostly handwritten over and over and over and over and over again, starting from the beginning. I never have been able to do it any other way. First word first. First syllable first, all the way to the end. Sometimes, I will have a whole... In fact, the happiest times, I will have a whole draft to work from. But there really isn't any way to formalize it because everyone's different. Every single piece I've ever written comes differently, has different problems.
William Maxwell said he learned nothing about writing the next novel from writing the last one. It does feel to me like sort of like I'm inventing the wheel every time and they just don't resemble each other. I have written poems in single drafts, not very often but I've also written 250 drafts of a poem and still not finished it, and it ends up in the brown box. I have finished poems that I started 25 years earlier because for whatever reason – you know, my life is changed, I've changed a little, I hope, and saw the solution to the problem, that was insoluble. Really, it's like doing problems, I think at that stage of composition, at least. The ideas kind of that you get something that compels you. Isn't that how it is?
DB: Yeah.
MR: It drives you through until it's finished and that finish may take a while or not. It might take forms, there can be snags along the way. There can be endings that don't come but it isn't linear. There are problems that occur, structural problems and so forth.
DB: In terms of how this is going kind of physically, so you say you just write a draft and you never like go back and cross that out, or do you write another draft and another draft and another draft all handwritten? I'm just trying to clarify.
MR: No, I will cross things out or write in alternatives on the side.
DB: On the one sheet of paper?
MR: Yeah. I don't recopy the whole draft every single time, which I guess is what I indicated before, but if it's just messing what tweaks. But sometimes the snag will get hit at line whatever, 5. Then, I will start all over again, or line 25. I just have to have the whole thing in my head. At a certain point, but rarely before a whole draft is there. I will go to the computer and type it up and then it helps to see it printed out. I don't work on the screen. Print it out and then work on it some more.
DB: Is the way that you do it with the computer now the same way that you used the typewriter?
MR: Essentially.
DB: Essentially?
MR: Yeah. I mean, I guess maybe sometimes I do...
[00:20:00] PART 2
MR: Like little changes on the screen. You know, if I'm typing it up again or something, you know, that will perhaps provoke probably minor changes, taking change again article or, you know.
DB: Yeah, but nothing, never anything very substantial.
MR: Well usually not, you know, as my recollection.
DB: And the handwriting the composition pieces, where did they exist physically, are they in a notebook? Are they on just regular pieces of paper or...?
MR: They are on yellow, well actually I do have...
DB: Did that change over the...
MR: You're making me see how idiosyncratic I am. I guess everybody probably is.
DB: Yeah, yeah.
MR: What I do is I take a piece of white typing paper, usually it has something written on the other side of it.
DB: Okay.
MR: I will fold it in half and I will start writing on one side of it, and, you know, and if that goes on, if it's longer than that, I will go to the other side.
DB: Yeah.
MR: And then I had to store them, you know, I will shove them together, you know, the way that they can be folded in inside and the latest one will be on top.
DB: Yeah.
MR: But also, I will also write on yellow pads, a metal coming to the process and then there are the typed sheets. It all sounds pretty chaotic when I say it or really compulsively.
DB: So is it usually that progression, it starts on typing paper, moves to the yellow sheets, and then to the computer?
MR: Well, it varies. Sometimes, there are no yellow sheets, but it will always go from, I will never start composing a poem on the typewriter.
DB: Okay.
MR: On a computer, ever, that doesn't happen. So it always goes that way.
DB: Now, in terms of your prose work, does that start on the computer?
MR: Mm-hmm.
DB: Okay.
MR: Yeah, for some reason, I can write prose on the computer and prefer to write it on the computer because I can change. I, you know, will change a lot as I am writing but why that would be specifically and, you know, it's so distinct from one to the other is a mystery to me, maybe just because that I originally wrote prose by hand too.
DB: Okay.
MR: I only stopped writing it by hand, I think, about 20 years ago. So I think I wrote Secret Life on the computer.
DB: On the computer?
MR: Maybe when computers came in.
DB: That was sort of, that has actually what led to...
MR: Yeah.
DB: ... more writing.
MR: I think mostly, yeah.
DB: Okay.
MR: Yeah, that was in the ‘80s.
DB: In the ‘80s, is that when you started...?
MR: Yeah, I had one of those enormous things with a huge processor.
DB: Yeah. Did you know the difference once you were moving- you weren't using the typewriter anymore and you moved to the computer, was there, what did that...?
MR: Well, one great thing about it was that you can make changes.
DB: Yeah.
MR: You know, and you don't have to retype the whole thing, which is what you have to do.
DB: Right.
MR: Before that.
DB: And have you composed prose longhand? I mean, did you ever do that?
MR: Yes, mostly essays.
DB: Mostly essays.
MR: In my book of essays which was published in 2000 were composed longhand.
DB: And those essays though, were they written initially earlier, I mean, I'm assuming quite much earlier than 2000?
MR: Quite a few of them were.
DB: Okay.
MR: And maybe the last ones in it were composed on a computer.
DB: Okay.
MR: It's in fact, likely.
DB: Yeah. So the computer came in in kind of the late ‘80s. Did you notice as like computing powers, computers got more powerful, did anything change then or does it feel basically the same since the first time?
MR: Well that first time before you were born.
DB: No, I was born.
MR: Yeah but they, you know, they were so slow...
[00:25:00]
MR: you know but at that time, it seemed like magic and just that being able to change it so yeah, of course it has changed everything. It has accelerated and you can look up stuff and look up definitions of words. I would always often write with a dictionary. I never have called a poem finished before I looked up most of the words in the poem. I like to see how the etymologies work in relationship to one another before I call something finished. Now you can do a lot of that on the computer.
DB: And now have you moved from using physical dictionaries to...?
MR: I still have them. They are next to my chair upstairs. I still like to do that but, yeah, I'm not systematic about it. I will look up things on the computer too.
DB: Okay. And so when you first started using the computer, were you also, all the time though, you were always printing out, you never really worked on the screen even in the early days to kind of...?
MR: Yes.
DB: And now we're going to move kind of the revision section. We're talking about both and that's fine.
MR: Okay.
DB: So you spoke some about your revision practices when you first started at being fairly small, was the book prompted this sort of the change to move into a more robust revision strategy?
MR: Well, the poem that I wanted, needed, could see to write couldn't be written in a single draft. So I just had to keep, I guess I got something that felt rich enough and compelling enough to keep pounding and that did seem to create a sort of breakthrough for me.
DB: Did you learn this revision technique? Was this sort of, did other people influence you in developing this or was it something that you kind of built...?
MR: Well, I had been taking workshop at the University of Iowa for a year but it's not my memory that we have really spoke about that and so it was really compelled from the inside out. It was more the piece just wouldn't yield and yet it wasn't going to be thrown away either, there was something in it. So I don't know, my relationship to the whole enterprise shifted and just started working more slowly in the sense of, no less, probably in fact more, and no more slowly, it just got finished a lot more slowly. And there are a lot less poems and now I write very few, I mean I write a lot of poems still but it seems like one out 100 starts, comes to fruition at most.
DB: Okay. Your sort of style of revision, are you adding or are you subtracting or are you sort of substituting, or is it a combination of those?
MR: I am pushing into it.
DB: Okay.
MR: I am pushing as far down into it and as far out as I can, I mean, with attention to all the aspects of poetry as I understand it and hope that the poem embodies, you know, Rich Wilbur said, "My intention in writing a poem is to exhaust the subject and don't ignore that." I don't ignore, in my own mind at least, anything. I want everything to be, you know, working on eight cylinders and of course I never achieve that. It's an impossible ideal but I'm trying to grow into the language, I'm trying to grow deeper into the subject. I'm trying to make the story, if there is one or one implicit I'm working with every aspect of it, but it's essentially, you know...
[00:30:00]
MR: ... getting aligned might be a beginning and it contained everything else. That's the weird and sort of mystical aspect. It's all in that piece but it's driving you to complete it.
DB: Yeah, and how did those lines come to you?
MR: Randomly. Sometimes when I'm reading, I was reading this morning and it's sparked something and I wrote it down, but it probably will never see the light of day. Middle of the night, I have to get up out of bed and turn on the light, write down the line, almost never sees the light of day, you know, and I have various repositories for these lines but it has gotten pretty disorganized too. I used to be a lot better at keeping them in one place, but I do try to dig it all out and look at it sometimes especially when I'm dry or because of teaching haven't been able to work on my writing for a while. So I'd get started again. I will just look at all these, what to me is raw material, but raw material can come from anywhere. It can come from somebody else's writing too, but it has mostly got to come from my own.
DB: And so for like a line that you wake up in the middle of the night to write down, what do you write it down on?
MR: Well, I can write it in my journal, I keep a journal now, a handwritten journal or I can just write it on a piece of folded paper.
DB: How is the journal related to the writing at this point? Have you been doing that your whole career or is that...?
MR: No I have been doing that for about the last 15 years. The journal for me is a separate enterprise. It's just the kind of vomiting, I pride when anybody else ever read but there is stuff in it sometimes you know, I have gone through the exhausting narcissistic process of rereading the journals sometimes and right now what I have started doing is I write the journal in black ink and if there's something that I want to remember for writing prose, poetry, I will underline it in blue so that I can go back through it and see what those things are.
DB: Okay. So you say that the pieces, you're still writing a lot but there are a lot more, a lot fewer that are coming up to that level, I mean, how has that changed over the course of your career, were they more kind of bubbling up or do you have higher standards at this point?
MR: It's not really standards.
DB: Okay.
MR: I mean, I want it to be as good as it can be always so the standard is, you know, that is the standard, whether or not I ever achieve it or how often I do is unfortunately not for me to say because I would say, you know, that it pretty much either achieves that standard and simultaneously doesn't, you know. So again, it's just my audience for a poem is the poem. I don't... what anybody else thinks of it or even what I think of it doesn't matter at all. To me what I want to do is get the poem to come off of the page and become a thing. So, you know, again, whether or not I'm doing that, that's sort of the illusion that I'm under.
DB: How do you know when it's a thing?
MR: I don't know except I do know. I mean, I'm talking like a Zen.
DB: Yes, yes. I mean, it is almost certain.
MR: I mean, I don't really know how to answer that because again, it depends upon the piece so it's contingent.
DB: Yeah.
MR: But it feels and seems and, you know, I interrogate my work brutally. I would never want anyone to talk to anyone else the way that...
[00:35:00]
MR: ...I talk to my poems. I ask them at every moment, "Are you interesting? Are you interesting? Are you interesting? Is this engaging?" Every nanosecond of the piece I want it to be. Keats said in his letters, he wanted to load every rift with ore and he meant, he was talking about sound mostly, you know, in that particular context but that's what I want to do. Every moment provides an opportunity and you just don't want to lose your attention to that.
DB: Right. And has that, I mean, have you gotten, has your definition of interesting become slimmer as you correct practices has been going forward or...?
MR: I think it has actually become wider. I think I'm a little bit, not much but a little less obsessive and a little less tunnel vision than I was when I was younger, but my taste has not really changed in music, in painting, in poetry, and you know, I've discovered new things along the way but I remember seemingly consistent, height bound.
DB: So what role do other people play in your revision process?
MR: Well, I have trusted readers, you know, that some of whom I've had for a very, very long time. I think what you want in a reader is somebody who loves your work and maybe loves you but will tell you the truth about a piece, even to the point of saying, you know, "This really doesn't work at all" and bones in the bone pile, but will tell you at every place that doesn't work for them and you can almost take, you know, and then if you can get a group of these responses and you can see which ones are useful. I've changed things because of those responses but I also have not changed things.
DB: How does that work kind of on a statistical way and has that changed pretty dramatically?
MR: No it hasn't.
DB: Okay.
MR: It's just a question, I mean it's like going to a shrink or something, or talking to a friend, or a spouse. It gives you new eyes. You need new eyes just to, you know, and then you're able to process that response because it's concrete. It's not abstract. You can only interrogate it so far by yourself and then you need somebody to tell you, "This is working, this isn't."
DB: Yeah, and in terms of like are you know sending these over email?
MR: Yeah.
DB: Before when there was no email?
MR: Through snail mail.
DB: Through regular mail but it's a similar process?
MR: Same thing.
DB: Same thing. Do you find the immediacy of email has changed it or...?
MR: We've become terribly spoiled by the immediacy of email. I mean, you send something off and you expect something is going to come back in the next 3 minutes.
DB: I know.
MR: If it's something you're particularly looking for, you check your email 712 times a day or, you know, so it takes a real discipline for me not to do that because I would spend all my time doing that otherwise.
DB: So this is the kind of organizational archival portion of the thing. How do kind of keep track of all the work that you have coming from beginning to end? Like, say, just one poem for instance, do you have many going at the same time or are you always working on one and then that comes and then you move on to the next?
MR: I never have been able to do more than one thing at a time, ever and so if I'm working on an essay, that's all I'm working on. If I'm working on a poem, that's all I'm working on. If I'm working on a nonfiction...
[00:40:00] PART 3
MR: at least, that's all I'm doing. I just don't have the capacity I might, you know, still have lines of poems in the middle of the night or come to me and I will write them down, but I don't work on those. I never bring anything to completion. Stop this and do this and go back to that. I just have to totally immerse myself in what I'm doing.
DB: And so, once that becomes version 10 or whatever on the computer and then you moved in onto the next, how do those then coalescence with collection?
MR: Well, I have the final drafts of each of the poems at a certain point. You know, most books of poems are about 40 poems, about 50, 60 pages, at least mine are. So, usually in, somewhere in the 30s, the book will start to take shape. There might be a great, a number of those that won't make it into the book. Some will seem too weak. I've published quite a few poems in magazines that didn't go into any collection ever and so there is a process of when I am at that point and even more revision of individual pieces. But I will take it out of the folder that it's in, you know, it will be X-10, Y-25 or whatever the piece is and then I'll take the final version and just save it into the book folder. Then I'll work, you know, I'm still working in the compositional folder but it will then be easily finished and these are going to go into a book.
DB: And then when you are putting together the order, when you have maybe all of the poems ready, how do you go about doing...?
MR: Well, print, printing. They will all be printed out in the final versions and I will mess with them, I mess with the paper. I couldn't do it any other way.
DB: Yeah. And do you have any other rituals or things for doing that, do you put them all out on the wall or something like that or?
MR: I've heard of people who do that, they spread them out on the floor and stuff but I've never done that. I do make sometimes arbitrary decisions, I basically don't like, though I used it earlier on sections, I don't do that anymore. I don't think it's in my last work actually, I should probably check. I mean, my preference is for it to be one thing.
DB: Yeah, indeed. So, some of this collection work did change over the course in that, I mean, just small things, but like you not using sections anymore and things like that. Do you notice any other changes from your earlier career to now?
MR: In terms of?
DB: Composing, say, the book as a whole once you're at that finished stage?
MR: No. I can't really say so. It's, again, a process of trying to realize it as best you can and also not publish it until it's ready to be published. And I certainly didn't choose to be, to take, it was... it's about 10 years between books of poems on the average but I also did write three other books. So, that took some time as well but I have never been anxious to put something out before I was happy with it.
DB: Okay. So, that's sort of the basic sort of process portion. Is there anything else you think you should mention or we should talk about before.... I mean this is going to get a little bit of that but this is kind of another sort of short answer, like a lot of these computer questions basically.
MR: Well, no.
DB: That's fine.
MR: I mean there's also infinite subjects to talk about but, you know, I think the most interesting part of this...
[00:45:00]
MR: ...for thinking about making it into a magazine thing was the question to my composition.
DB: Yeah. So, these are kind of the more, I guess, wonder questions about computer use and I think we mentioned some of these. So, when did you start using computers kind of on a regular basis, Late 80s?
MR: Probably mid-80s.
DB: Mid-80s?
MR: It was pretty early.
DB: Okay and how did you have access to a computer? Was it a personal computer?
MR: I bought it.
DB: You bought it?
MR: Yeah, cost a lot of money too, at least, I didn't have much at the time.
DB: Yeah. What drove you to make that purchase if it was a larger one?
MR: Friends had told me or writers said that, "You've got to do this, this is amazing and wonderful, and do it."
